metadata.name: Olorì
metadata.description:
Olorì
This portrait was created to celebrate the cultural significance of women from the Alkebulan continent using the culture of the Yorùbá people.

The cloth is called Aṣọ Òkè native to the Yorùbá people of modern-day Nigeria.

The hairstyle is called Shuku which denotes royalty.

On the braids is attached 16 cowries (Agba mẹ́rìndínlógún).The 16 cowries represent the 16 Odu of ifa corpus.As Cowries were not just a means of exchange of the Yorùbá people it also holds spiritual significance in divination, fertility, and protection.It was handed over by ọrunmila to his wife Oṣunlẹyọ for easier communication with him spiritually whenever he is on his missionary travels.

The bigger sea shell is called Ìyá Ajé.Ajé is the òrìṣà (deity) of wealth and prosperity.Ajé is one of the children of Olókùn.The deity of the oceans and all water bodies.The slit on the shell sees and wards off evil.

Ori (head) is the representation of one’s spiritual essence.

She is Olorì,the Queen mother of mankind.
